July 8, 2007: Fiction
LEAN MEAN THIRTEEN, by Janet Evanovich. (St. Martin’s, $27.95.) The New
Jersey bounty hunter Stephanie Plum becomes a suspect when her ex-husband
disappears.
A THOUSAND SPLENDID SUNS, by Khaled Hosseini. (Riverhead, $25.95.) A
friendship between two women in Afghanistan against the backdrop of 30 years of
war.
BLAZE, by Richard Bachman. (Scribner, $25.) An early Stephen King novel —
Bachman is his alias — here revised. A criminal who was an abused child plots a
kidnapping.
DOUBLE TAKE, by Catherine Coulter. (Putnam, $25.95.) Dillon Savich and Lacey
Sherlock — F.B.I. agents as well as husband and wife — join with a San
Francisco colleague to solve a murder and find a missing woman.
THE NAVIGATOR, by Clive Cussler with Paul Kemprecos. (Putnam, $26.95.) Kurt
Austin and his team track down a stolen Phoenician statue.
THE GOOD GUY, by Dean Koontz. (Bantam, $27.) An ordinary man finds himself
at the center of a murder plot.
THE OVERLOOK, by Michael Connelly. (Little, Brown, $21.99.) The Los Angeles
detective Harry Bosch tangles with the F.B.I. and Homeland Security.
THE HARLEQUIN, by Laurell K. Hamilton. (Berkley, $25.95.) The vampire hunter
Anita Blake is under surveillance by a troop of vampire enforcers.
ON CHESIL BEACH, by Ian McEwan. (Nan A. Talese, $22.) A wedding night goes
terribly wrong.
THE 6TH TARGET, by James Patterson and Maxine Paetro. (Little, Brown,
$27.99.) Detective Lindsay Boxer and the Women’s Murder Club investigate the
disappearance of several children in San Francisco.
FOR ONE MORE DAY, by Mitch Albom. (Hyperion, $21.95.) A troubled man gets
a last chance to reconnect and restore his relationship with his dead mother.
THE BOURNE BETRAYAL, by Eric Van Lustbader. (Warner, $25.99.) Continuing
the story of Robert Ludlum’s character Jason Bourne, who tangles with a group of
diabolical Islamic terrorists.
THE CHILDREN OF HÚRIN, by J. R. R. Tolkien. Edited by Christopher Tolkien.
Illustrated by Alan Lee. (Houghton Mifflin, $26.) In Middle-earth, an evil lord wants
to destroy his rival’s children.
INNOCENT AS SIN, by Elizabeth Lowell. (Morrow, $24.95.) A banker unjustly
July 8, 2007
Non-Fiction
THE DIANA CHRONICLES, by Tina Brown. (Doubleday, $27.50.) The Princess of
Wales’s romance with the media.
THE REAGAN DIARIES, by Ronald Reagan. Edited by Douglas Brinkley.
(HarperCollins, $35.) Selections from the 40th president’s daily White House
diaries.
THE ASSAULT ON REASON, by Al Gore. (Penguin Press, $25.95.) How the Bush
administration has degraded the political environment through secrecy, fear and
the rejection of fact-based reasoning.
GOD IS NOT GREAT, by Christopher Hitchens. (Twelve, $24.99.) Religion as a
malignant force in the world.
OUTRAGE, by Dick Morris and Eileen McGann. (HC/HarperCollins, $26.95.) An
attack on illegal immigration, United Nations profiteers, lazy congressmen and
high drug prices.
LONE SURVIVOR, by Marcus Luttrell with Patrick Robinson. (Little, Brown,
$24.99.) The only survivor of a Navy Seal operation in northern Afghanistan
describes the battle, his comrades and his courageous escape.
EINSTEIN, by Walter Isaacson. (Simon & Schuster, $32.) A biography based on
newly released personal letters.
A LONG WAY GONE, by Ishmael Beah. (Sarah Crichton/Farrar, Straus & Giroux,
$22.) A former child soldier from Sierra Leone describes his drug-crazed killing
spree and his return to humanity.
PRESIDENTIAL COURAGE, by Michael Beschloss. (Simon & Schuster, $28.)
Profiles of nine presidents who had the courage to make unpopular decisions.
ANIMAL, VEGETABLE, MIRACLE, by Barbara Kingsolver with Steven L. Hopp
and Camille Kingsolver. (HarperCollins, $26.95.) The novelist and her family
spend a year eating homegrown or local food.
TALES FROM Q SCHOOL, by John Feinstein. (Little, Brown, $26.99.) Inside the
PGA 2005 Tour Qualifying Tournament, from the author of "A Good Walk
Spoiled."
I FEEL BAD ABOUT MY NECK, by Nora Ephron. (Knopf, $19.95.) A witty look at
aging from a novelist and screenwriter (“When Harry Met Sally”).
PLATO AND A PLATYPUS WALK INTO A BAR, by Thomas Cathcart and Daniel
Klein. (Abrams Image, $18.95.) A humorous tour of philosophical traditions.
